page.title: 03COLLIERY AT HICKLETON MAIN
page.content: Work on Hickleton Main first started in{1894.}It was deepened between 1921 to 1923. The Colliery itself was owned privately until 1947. When the pit first opened{3024}people worked there, now there are 217 men working there. The number of men who worked there at its peak was{3500}people. Hickleton Main has{three shafts.}One of them is the{last steam shaft}in the North of England. It is{60}years old. The underground workings are now three miles square. The pit has one coal cutting machine for digging. In the next two years the Colliery is going through a development programme which includes taking the steam winding machinery out. The machinery will go to a museum. This development programme will make the number of men working there{500}and bring coal production to{500,000 tonnes}a year.
